comments.commentBody: I don't understand where comments like this are coming from. Nate's model did not show a fairly large swing in voter sentiment towards Obama over the last 3 weeks of the campaign. Except for a short time immediately following the first debate, Obama's lead over Romney in Nate's model remained remarkably consistent for a significant period of time. Are people confusing 'Chance of Winning' with the size of Obama's lead? Obama's chances of winning increased as the election drew neared, but the size of his projected lead didn't (or at least not by very much).
I said this to another commenter. In a few weeks (or months), after her break at a spa, she can start her campaign.

I have every admiration for Hillary Clinton (though I supported Barack in '08). And I think she has every right to be exhausted, given the energy she has given for the last four years. And she should do with her future exactly what she wants, even if that were to be going into a Martha Stewart phase.

I respect, and share, Gail's appreciation of Mrs. Clinton, and the positive views expressed by commentators. And she deserves the approbation.

But people, think about it. Do we really want to start the 2016 campaign now? I don't think that was Gail's real point, but let's be careful. Hillary needs a rest, but so do I. So, I think, do we all.

I think it varies by poll, A previous poster here mentioned that Rand used a probability-to-vote approach (obviously better from a statistical perspective) whereas most polls just identify voters as likely or not. But I'm by no means an authoritative source.
MVH1:  Take a look at the Washington Post and probably (by now) elsewhere. The two-women aspect of the story is very much part of the story.
doug l --- In WA there will be a US$100 addition to the annual license fee for electric cars.  Not sure about hybrids.

The physical chemistry of tri-atomic gases is thoroughly understood and has been essentially settled since at least 1975: as more CO2 (a tri-atomic gas, Adrian O) is added to the atmosphere the global temperature will inexorably rise.
False to the point of lying as well.  I used that phrase exactly once.
They have amply demonstrated that a higher tax rate would not impoverish them. They have money to burn!
Of course they (whoever "they" are) would threaten to tell the spouse. That's the point.
Finally! A systems thinker looks at the relationship between global warming and an extreme weather event. Thank you, Sir.
Thanks for a more realistic view, Prof. Greene.

Charles H. Greene, a professor of earth and atmospheric sciences at Cornell, sent this reaction to Kevin Trenberth's view of the human influence on Sandy (and my interpretation):

I am not so sure that I agree with your take nor Kevin Trenberth's on Sandy .

"Indeed, in the case of Hurricane Sandy, any role for greenhouse gases was a background influence, even according to Kevin Trenberth of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, who’s been one of the most vocal scientists using extreme weather to make a case for emissions action. But of course, the extent of destruction from the storm surge came because a tiny bit of extra sea height can hugely amplify a storm’s impact."

Greenhouse gases may have been "a background influence" for Hurricane Sandy; however, were they a background influence for hybrid superstorm Sandy?

Sandy was only a modest late-season hurricane as it started its northward track from the Caribbean. Yes, the Atlantic Ocean temperatures were markedly warmer than the long-term average, but Sandy still weakened to tropical-storm strength by the time it moved north of Cape Hatteras, NC. That is when "a series of unfortunate events happened."

First, an unusually strong high-pressure blocking pattern over Greenland and the North Atlantic closed the door for Sandy to head northeast out to sea like most October hurricanes/tropical storms heading along such a trajectory. In fact, Sandy did not just track north over New England like the few other October hurricanes/tropical storms that did not head out to sea (think the 1991 Perfect Storm) ; rather, she did something never observed before (records going back to 1851) - she turned due west towards the most populated area in North America.

Second, while on this historically unprecedented westward trajectory, Sandy converged with an early "winter" nor'easter associated with an invasion of cold Arctic air into the middle latitudes. This transformed Sandy from a weakening October hurricane/tropical storm into an extra-tropical hybrid superstorm, one with the lowest atmospheric pressures ever recorded north of Cape Hatteras, NC and the second-largest extent (1000 km) of any extra-tropical storm derived from a hurricane (only behind 2001's Hurricane Olga).

Third, the historically unprecedented westward trajectory of Sandy led to the storm surge hitting the coasts of New York and New Jersey at an angle of incidence contributing to record high storm surges that exceeded the worst-case scenarios of models for parts of New York City.

Now, one might argue that these were just a series of unfortunate events resulting from the coincidence of many rare and/or unprecedented acts of nature. However, there is increasing evidence that the loss of summertime Arctic sea ice due to greenhouse warming stacks the deck in favor of 1) more frequent invasions of Arctic air masses into the middle latitudes, 2) more frequent nor'easters associated with such invasions, and 3) more frequent blocking events of the kind that steered Sandy to the west. If one accepts this evidence and line of reasoning, and also takes into account the record loss of Arctic sea ice this past September, then perhaps the likelihood of greenhouse warming playing a significant role in Sandy's evolution as an extra-tropical superstorm is at least as plausible as the idea that she was simply a freak of nature.

And, the arrival of a second nor'easter a few days later, which set some snowfall records in certain areas while making residents along the eastern seaboard even more miserable, just makes the largely an act of nature argument not very convincing to me.

http://www.geo.cornell.edu/geology/faculty/Greene.html

Even the older folks usd ad time to make popcorn or throw laundry in the dryer. We never listened to any with the sound up. But these old guys still think Limbaugh is cutting edge on AM radio, so they deserve the shock of the old.
One big mistake they made was thinking that tv ads mattered. The young people who elected the president watch tv sows on their laptops and smartphones. They never even saw the tv ads.
" ...a label of GMO is an implicit statement that there is something dangerous..." How so?

So I have to believe what you believe? No one is forcing you to believe they are harmful.Why don't I get a choice? What if you're wrong?
How about no labeling for origin? Whether it's made In the USA or wherever, no consumer should ever have the right to choose based on the their own opinion about a product ?

This comment is indicative of the level of ignorance exploited by big Agra. I voted because I "believe" something, not an evidence based assessment and rationale decision process but an opinion based on some feeling of what is true. I'll tell you what, how about they label our food accurately and then your free to eat whatever you "believe" is safe. For my part I'll pass on the poorly tested GMO foods and other adulterated items that wouldn't have passed for food only a generation or so ago. Oh and by the way more than a few studies have been buried because the didn't say what these companies wanted you to "believe"
I voted against it because I believe that a label of GMO is an implicit statement that there is something dangerous about GMOs, and I don't believe that to be true.

Ironic that, despite the harping and carping of the right wing that polls were skewed toward Democrats, they were actually skewed toward Republicans.  People with a firm grasp on facts, statistics, science, and reality would be chastened.  So of course the shrill right wing won't be.  They'll find a scapegoat (It was the hurricane!  How dare Americans observe a reasonable Presidential response to a disaster and compare it to the last President's?).

No matter what Hillary Clinton decides to do in the future she has established her place in American history and is a much admired person world wide. She is a statesman,  politically astute and experienced, tough minded, exceptionally intelligent, a political centrist who believes in the core values of  mainstream America and the Democratic party  and is demographically attuned the changes of the 21st century. In short she would be qualified for the presidency and make anyone that the GOP could field look like a pygmy. On the other hand she is 65 years old which sounds about right for someone who is 78 and she is in good condition just worked to a frazzle and needing a rest.  The time for a decision is right after the results of the 2014 midterm elections. Unless she decides to retire, then would be the time for start raising funds and and telling Joe Biden that he is going to be Secretary of State.
Its called The Big Lie, practiced with great effect in the 30s and 40s, a strategy conservatives are well versed in.
I believe you are referring to an already existing book, "Lies and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them."

It goes back a bit further, Ecce Homo, to the early 1960s. Television brought the civil-rights struggle into America's living rooms, and the unreconstructed had to find a way to spin it. WRAL-TV in Raleigh aired nightly editorials decrying, among other things, liberal bias in the media.

The editorialist was a broadcast executive named Jesse Helms. I wonder what became of him.

I found it interesting that most of the polls underestimated Obama's.vote while Fox and friends continually argued about the media bias against conservatives.  Somebody needs to write a book about all this "made-up" stuff that can be demonstrably shown to be just made up.  We need to recall and reinforce this misinformation from the Republicans the next time around.

Vince, it's the spouse or other "interested party" who would need to do the accepting, not the general public, who mostly don't care at all. It would be pretty harsh to expect spouses to shut up and suffer.

Nate, Many thanks and much gratitude for the great work, and the extraordinary ability to explain... and to entertain.

I too have had positions of being a "truth teller" and of telling truth that interferes with wealth and power. I regret the personal attacks that you suffered.Your humor and dignity and patient facts were exemplary.Please stay in the game.

I appreciated the polling analysis, particularly to maintain my sanity at the end. However, the seminal post for me was your August 30 post "Base Turnout Stategy May Be Too Narrow for Romney". Here, we learned that if Obama maintained his margins among minorities (never in doubt) and if turnout was at least moderate (if the Dem coalition voted), even 65% of the white vote would not do it for Romney.

It appears that Wednesday was when the rest of the world started doing the algebra, and found it revelatory.

The second most astonishing thing is that after the Dem coaltion was in line at early voting in big volumes, the pundits and Romney campaign convinced themselves that the people who had actually already voted were not voting.

I wanted Obama to win because I believe he will build a better and greater America. However, I am very relieved that folks capable of this degree of delusion are kept away from nuclear weapons, and other things dangerous to the human race.
3 fingers up, wags, chicago contingent, still wearing the neckerchiefs that prove it, scout's honor...can all y'all dig it!

She's a smart woman who has exceeded expectations and has an incredible ability to concentrate on the job to get things done.  Give her credit for learning lessons.  I'm sure that if she runs again, she will apply lessons from the first time around.

I think Bill Clinton's support for Obama was a down payment for the Obama relection team in 2016.  In Iowa, noting this would be his last presidential campaign speech, President Obama added "for me."  He'll be there too.

My main concern about a Hillary 2016 run -- or indeed, the run of any Democrat to succeed Barack Obama -- is what type of campaign they would run, and whom they would bring in to run it.

It's easy to forget now, but in 2008, Clinton had a horribly run campaign that was centered on big beltway egos, and was openly dismissive of the sort of grassroots, data-driven campaign behind Obama, which in the end ground her aspirations into the dust. It is Obama's sort of campaign -- one centered on person-to-person contact, one that sees the high-priced headquarters staff as tools of the grassroots organizers rather than their bosses, and one that understands that for a progressive to be elected, running a "conventional", ad-based campaign simply won't work -- that we needed in 2008, in 2012, and will need again in the future.

Obama owes his re-election in no small part to the incredible machinery of local organizers and volunteers that he's built over the past 5 years (and which is itching to be deployed in 2014 to avoid another midterm fiasco). Who will recognize this, and build on it? If Clinton does, and will, I'll be behind her 100%. If she chooses to run, and her first choice is giving a hefty paycheck to some Beltway crank like Mark Penn or Howard Wolfson again, well...

I'm a nurse, and a patient I had in her her 90's recently exclaimed to me (when I told her how impressed I was with her health, her outlook, her quality of life) "Why, honey! Ninety is the new Eighty, it's no big deal!"

Hillary at only 70, losing her edge? Nah.

I am 78 and I know exactly what you are talking about. Well, if she stops flying around the world and takes very good care of herself, perhaps becomes a vegan (not a mere vegetarian), she may be OK for the first term.

Second? Hardly, but she can select a youngster for her VP and annoint him/her for the second term.

Am I fantasizing? Very likely.

Hillary would hve been the perfect first woman president. Unhappily, she will be approaching 70 when her next opportunity occurs. I yield to no one in my admiration for her, but I am 76 and remember well the difference in my energy and acuity between age 50 and age 70. I wish I could deny the impact of age, but we do slow down and lose our edge, and I have to think Hillery, despite her commitment to working out and resting up, will experience the inevitable decline that age impose.

Having said that, I look forward to the great role Hillary will no doubt play in this nation's continuing social and intellectual growth.
My guess is that the money still bought itself a seat at the table for the fiscal cliff negotiations.

"...oppose an overweening and intrusive state while still recognizing that “government can give average people a hand up to achieve the American Dream.” It should be possible for the party to reform and streamline government while also addressing middle-class anxieties about wages, health care, education and more."

I think you just described the platform of the Democratic Party.

Being elderly, I have 'memories' of many men in power in our government who had 'affairs'.  Eisenhower for one and he wasn't 'kicked out'.  FDR also had a lover for years.  He had his own 'train' and 'parked' it on a side rail outside of Hackettstown, NJ for his picadillos.  How about JFK??  AND, if it is to be believed, even in the Oval Office.  Using a key 'word' our government agents can find out about 'anything' on line.  Gee, I almost forgot, Bill Clinton, like Kennedy.  All I know is that i'ts a shame that some let what's between their legs decide their future instead of what's in their heads.....it's really sad when these men have had so much to offer.
To all who cite the UMCJ: we just changed it about being gay, now we should change it about adultery. This is primitive law.
We expect better from our so called leaders, to have foresight, which apparently this man did not have thus he does not deserve the job he is in!

As reported I cannot see why Petraeus would feel the need to resign, he has been through much worse in army conflicts and has the ability to function well under pressure - which would have subsided if he rode it through. Unless of course there is more that has not been reported or discovered. I hope not. This is an unfortunate outcome for all concerned.

Silver's conclusions are based on his processing of data collected elsewhere.  So  Silver could not be said to have an average error.  His corrections were not completely accurate but still pretty good.

These PACs ran the most negative ads I have ever seen, although what I have read of some of the early campaigns were even worse and today would be slander.

But the ads this time either exaggerated or distorted the opponents record and views. For instance if a candidate had said he might consider raising the gas tax if it was needed for a particular purpose, the opposition ran an ad that said he was going to raise your gas price to $6 a gallon.

Our favorite candidate is a licensed physician who taught at a university, was assistant director of admissions, and had been the county medical officer. He still does voluntary work but has managed to become well off in real estate. His opponents ads called him a landlord and real estate speculator, and said he had not been a doctor for several years. But he is winning at the moment.

Negative ads are O.K. if they are accurate, but when they are not and can be shown to be wrong or even plain lies, then the promoter loses. We saw the Romney ads about Jeep moving to China, and distortions about the auto bailout; they were demonstrable false.

If the supporters of these super rich PACs can not tell the truth from fiction, that shows just how bankrupt they are. And if they do know the facts and still lie about them, that makes them and their candidate unfit for public office.

The news organizations must be brought to publish these prevarications and inform the public. They have become too cautious in their neutrality.
